data.title: Why was Saddam Hussein haunted by the brutal murder of Iraq's boy king?
data.meta_description: Waiting in a spartan, concrete-lined chamber at Camp Justice, an Iraqi army base in Kazimain, a north-eastern suburb of Baghdad, the 69-year-old fallen dictator Saddam Hussein, dressed in a black overcoat, stood on the trapdoor of the gallows.
data.text:
Waiting in a spartan, concrete-lined chamber at Camp Justice, an Iraqi army base in Kazimain, a north-eastern suburb of Baghdad, the 69-year-old fallen dictator Saddam Hussein, dressed in a black overcoat, stood on the trapdoor of the gallows.

Found guilty of crimes against humanity during his 24 years as President of Iraq, he had been sentenced to death.

But even now, in his last moments, he maintained his old defiance.

Saddam Hussein moments before his death

Spurning the use of a black hood over his head, he shouted 'Allah is great', as three masked executioners placed the rope around his throat.

The platform dropped and there was an audible crack, indicating that his neck was broken. One of modern history's most ruthless tyrants was dead at last.

Only moments before the end, on December 30, 2006, Shi'ite observers at the execution had hurled sectarian insults at Saddam (a Sunni), taunting him with the name of his great antagonist, the radical Shi'ite cleric Moqtada Sadr.

'Moqtada! Moqtada!' they jeered. Saddam repeated the name mockingly, adding: 'Do you consider this bravery?'

But despite the hopes and jubilation of his enemies, Saddam's thoughts in those final moments are unlikely to have been of Moqtada, but of another much younger man - one born only two years before himself: the tragic last King of Iraq, whose brutal murder 50 years ago this summer not only shocked and horrified the world, but haunted and obsessed Saddam for the rest of his days.

In the dock: Saddam Hussein was obsessed by the murdered boy king of Iraq Faisal II

Last week, BBC2 began screening a four-part drama series, House Of Saddam, charting the Iraqi dictator's journey from ambitious young law student to all-powerful tyrant to the bedraggled, long-bearded tramp captured by American forces in December 2003.

The series is a terrifying study of the ruthless pursuit of power, but it does not mention Iraq's last monarch, Faisal II, with whom Saddam - who was only 21 when the King was butchered - was to become fixated, despite his own hostility to the monarchy.

Why was it that the young King's horrific death at the age of 23 filled the republican Saddam with an overwhelming sense of shame?

Why, at the zenith of his power as the ruler of Iraq, did Saddam provide the murdered monarch with a magnificent new marble tomb?

And why, even more astonishingly, did he make frequent and secret visits to King Faisal's grave, even ordering the cemetery officials to open the royal tomb so that he might gaze in morbid fascination at the last sovereign's mutilated and mangled remains?

Was it because he somehow already had a premonition that his own end would be every bit as macabre as that of the far more decent, honourable and innocent young man who had perished all those years before him?

The saga begins some 17 years before Saddam's birth. After the end of World War I, Britain, France and the United States seized the rights to 95 per cent of the oil in Iraq.

In 1920, the newly-formed League of Nations granted Britain a mandate over Iraq in the form of a kind of pre-independence trusteeship.

King Faisal who was brutally murdered at the age of 23

As Colonial Secretary, Winston Churchill presided over the Cairo conference in 1921 and decided upon the creation of an artificial monarchy in Iraq, forcing three radically different groups - the Sunni Muslim Kurds, the Sunni Muslim Arabs and the Shi'ite Muslims - to combine under a single ruler.

Churchill's resolve was to have calamitous consequences. Today's map of the Middle East, the rise of Saddam Hussein, the Gulf Wars of 1991 and 2003, and the current bloodshed and schism in Iraq are the unwitting legacies of that decision.

The Hashemite constitutional monarchy imposed on Iraq by the British was headed by 35-year-old King Faisal I, who was born in what is now Saudi Arabia, had never set foot in Iraq, spoke an Arabic dialect that was barely intelligible to his future subjects, and had no knowledge of the disparate Iraqi tribes.

Faisal spent his 12-year reign attempting to hold the balance between British interests in his kingdom and Iraqi suspicions over his alleged pro-Western sympathies.

The strain undermined his health, and he died from a heart attack at 48 within a week of his arrival.

Faisal's son, King Ghazi, a 21-year-old playboy who resented British domination, inherited the throne but six years later, in 1939, he crashed his sports car in Baghdad after a night of heavy drinking and died from his injuries.

The crown then fell to the playboy's only son, four-year-old King Faisal II, who began his reign under the regency of his repressive and hugely unpopular maternal uncle, Crown Prince Abdullah.

Faisal II was educated in Britain at Harrow, along with his cousin, King Hussein of Jordan.

Faisal, the intelligent ruler of a rich country, appeared destined for greatness. Hussein, king of a penniless backwater, described by his housemaster as 'not a success at Harrow', seemed bound to fail.

Iraqi Sunni Arabs pray at Saddam Hussein's own grave in his home village of Awja

On May 2, 1953, both 18-year-old cousins were enthroned as monarchs in separate ceremonies in Baghdad and Amman.

Watching from the crowd, as King Faisal II arrived to take the oath before Parliament, was 16-year-old Saddam Hussein, who would later tell King Hussein that although he was not in sympathy with the policies of the monarchy, he was 'intrigued and fascinated by the character and bearing of the young King'.

But the tide was turning against the Hashemite dynasty. King Faisal II remained committed to his grand-father's pro-British policies, the unpopularity of which increased ten-fold in 1956, following British, French and American opposition to Egypt's seizure of the Suez Canal.

Tragically, it was his close alliance with his cousin King Hussein, the man he trusted most in the world, that led to Faisal's destruction.

In the summer of 1958, King Hussein asked for Iraqi military assistance during an escalating crisis in Lebanon where civil war looked certain to break out.

On July 13, two infantry brigades of the Iraqi army received orders to proceed to Jordan, via Baghdad.

That night, King Faisal II, the hated and still hugely influential Crown Prince and other members of the Royal Family were in their palace in Baghdad.

Brigadier Abdul Karim Qassim, a disaffected Iraqi officer in command of the two brigades, realised that he had a 'now or never' chance to use his mobilised troops to overthrow the regime - and instead of sending them on towards Jordan, he directed them towards the Qasr Rihab palace.

There is clear evidence that the British and American governments had advance intelligence of the planned coup, but all their energies at that time were channelled into supporting the beleaguered King Hussein.

By a curious coincidence, my sister, Jean Thornton, then 27 and working for Shell in Iran, also had disturbing evidence of what was about to happen.

Driving with a group of British and American friends across the border to a dinner-dance in Baghdad, they encountered road-blocks, a curfew in operation and armed guards pointing machine guns at their car.

For a moment, the situation seemed perilous. Then my sister turned to an American woman and urged: 'Show them your new Polaroid camera. Take their picture with it.'

The Iraqi guards, never having seen a Polaroid camera, were so delighted by their instant photos that they waved the group through, though it was only for the party to discover that the event to which they were travelling had been abruptly cancelled.

Some time after 5.30 on the morning of July 14, 1958, the palace in Baghdad was surrounded by tanks. They opened fire, causing thick columns of smoke to billow from the upper floors of the building.

Crown Prince Abdullah, realising that the palace was surrounded, ordered the royal guards to surrender, and to fly a white flag from the roof.

A little before eight o'clock, the 23-year- old King Faisal II, who was engaged to be married, his uncle, the Crown Prince Abdullah, Princess Abadiya (the King's aunt), Princess Nafeesa (Abdullah's mother), Abdullah's six-year- old nephew, a group of Arab maidservants and Pakistani cooks stumbled out of the rear entrance of the blazing palace to confront a semi- circle of armed officers.

They were asked to turn to face the wall.

What happened next is not clear - there are any number of conflicting accounts. It appears that the plan was to take the King alive.

But from the front entrance of the palace, emerging at a run, with a submachine gun in his hand, came an officer, Captain Abdus Sattar As Sab, who was overcome by the situation.

Later claiming that he was 'in a state of frenzy' and felt as if 'a black cloud' had covered his vision, he opened fire on the Royal Family, killing them all with the possible exception of the King, who, according to some accounts, did not die immediately.

One eye-witness, however, an assistant cook at the royal palace, who suffered a traumatic amputation of one arm in the attack, insisted that he was 'absolutely certain' that he had seen the King killed by the fire of automatic weapons which the troops used upon all assembled there.

The cook thought the troops then beheaded the King.

King Faisal's body was taken to the Royal Hospital in Baghdad where, after some days, witnesses were allowed to see it in order to prove that the King was really dead.

The first lorry-load of bodies from the Palace was inspected by a doctor who was so horrified at the extent of mutilation that he was unable to decide whether the women were of the Royal Family or servants of the household.

The body of the hated Crown Prince was turned over to the mob. The hands and feet were hacked off and carried through the streets on spikes.

The naked and mutilated body was then dragged to the Ministry of Defence, where it was hanged by the neck from the balcony.

The Prime Minister, Nuri es Said, who had escaped from Baghdad dressed as a woman, was captured and shot, his body disembowelled and dragged through the streets by the mob.

'Finally,' records one secret Foreign Office report, 'a car was driven backwards and forwards over it until it was flattened into the ground.'

One British diplomat, Charles Johnston-in a secret report to Whitehall, wrote: 'I have left out a number of horrors (mutilation, cannibalism etc) - and am not enclosing a gruesome photograph of the Crown Prince's body hanging from the balcony.

'If the Russian Revolution had been put into execution by the Mau Mau, the effect would not have been very much different.'

However, over the murder of the young King, who had lived modestly and was innocent of all taint of corruption, there was, according to the British Ambassador, Sir Michael Wright, 'evidence of widespread shame and grief'.

The distinguished British historian Jane Priestland, editor of Records Of Iraq, 1914-1966, says: 'I have no doubt at all that the British government had advance knowledge of the coup.

'There are documents in existence, that have not been released, that would substantiate this.'

When, in October 2006, she made a Freedom of Information request for the release of these documents, it was refused by the Foreign Office on the grounds that 'this could increase the instability in an already volatile area of the world'.

King Faisal's body was buried in strict secrecy at the Hashemite royal cemetery in Adhamiya, north of Baghdad.

And there it lay virtually forgotten for 21 years, until Saddam Hussein seized power in 1979, the point at which this week's television series began.

To the astonishment of his entourage, Saddam, the new President of Iraq, began to make secret visits to King Faisal's tomb. On some occasions, he remained inside the royal mausoleum for more than an hour.

In 1982, Saddam arranged for King Hussein of Jordan - who, unlike his less fortunate cousin, had survived wars and countless assassination attempts as he walked a tightrope across the abyss of Middle Eastern politics - to come to Adhamiya to visit King Faisal's final resting place.

In that same year, by presidential decree, Saddam remodelled the royal cemetery, providing Iraq's last King with a magnificent new marble tomb.

Some whispered that the President 'believed himself to be of Hashemite descent'; others that he was merely obsessed and fixated by Faisal II's tragically brief life and reign.

On several occasions, Saddam astonished the cemetery officials by asking for the marble slab that covered Faisal's grave to be removed, and for the royal coffin, sealed for more than a quarter of a century, to be opened for his inspection.

Was it the corpse of the murdered monarch at which Saddam gazed with such morbid fascination? Or was it the spectre of his own destiny?

That destiny closed in upon him all too rapidly after the fall of Baghdad on April 9, 2003.

His sons Uday and Qusay and his 14-year-old grandson Mustapha were killed in a three-hour gunfight with American forces three months later, followed by the humiliating capture of the bearded and dishevelled Saddam himself at a farmhouse in ad-Dawr, near his native Tikrit in December.

After the invasion that ousted him from power, American forces for a time occupied the royal cemetery at Adhamiya, damaging the tomb of Faisal II's grandfather, when they searched it for weapons, and also several of the chandeliers in the mosque.

Protests by the local Iraqi population eventually forced the Americans to withdraw.

'Now no one dares to come here,' says the royal cemetery guard, Ghanem Jamil Ali. 'If you go to the main gate, you will see a tank in front of it.'

Yet there, among the evergreen trees and close to the historic Tigris River, stands the strangest and most mysterious relic of Saddam's 24-year reign: his monument to the tragic young King he regarded as a royal martyr.
